questions.hint: Falls are a common problem, even in well-controlled Parkinson disease, mainly because of postural instability and unsteady gait.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old woman with a 7-year history of Parkinson disease reports hallucinations, confusion, and worsening motor function. She is currently taking extended-release ropinirole 16 mg daily. On physical examination, she is akinetic and rigid with no tremor. She has a prominent gait disorder and postural instability.
Which one of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Increase the dose of the extended-release ropinirole
Plan for deep-brain stimulation of the bilateral subthalamic nucleus
Add carbidopa-levodopa to the existing regimen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing the ropinirole dose would be likely to worsen the hallucinations.

B) INCORRECT:

In an older patient with diminished cognitive and behavioral reserve, amantadine should be avoided, as it is only modestly effective in controlling motor symptoms yet can cause confusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Deep-brain stimulation would not be appropriate in an older patient with confusion and hallucinations, particularly one whose medication regimen has not been optimized.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with Parkinson disease is undermedicated to manage her motor difficulties, yet she is having hallucinations related to her use of ropinirole. Although dopamine agonists may be appropriate in younger patients with Parkinson disease, they are not as well tolerated by older patients and may produce hallucinations and confusion. Carbidopa-levodopa can deliver a potent antiparkinsonian benefit in older patients and is better tolerated.

Key learning point: In an older patient with Parkinson disease who reports worsening motor function and hallucinations while taking daily ropinirole, the most appropriate treatment option is to replace the ropinirole with carbidopa-levodopa.

E) INCORRECT:

A combination of dopamine agonists and carbidopa-levodopa therapy would not help with the hallucinations.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man complains of tremor with insidious onset and gradual worsening during the past year. The tremor is worse at rest and affects his fingers and wrist on the left side. Symptoms have become more noticeable in the past 3 months but are not disabling. There is a vague family history of tremor.
Which one of the following examination findings is necessary to make a diagnosis of Parkinson disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Micrographia is present in most patients with Parkinson disease but is not among the defining criteria for Parkinson disease, given that it is present in approximately 10% of older patients.

B) CORRECT:

Tremor, which has many causes, is the most common movement disorder encountered in clinical practice. The best diagnostic approach is a detailed clinical evaluation, including history of recent exposure to potentially tremorogenic medications, possibility of hyperthyroidism, and examination to characterize the tremor.

Parkinson disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disease whose usual initial symptom is tremor. The diagnosis of PD is made clinically. The examination must identify a parkinsonian syndrome, which is defined as bradykinesia plus at least one of the following three findings: muscular rigidity, rest tremor, and postural instability.

Bradykinesia is mandatory to establish a parkinsonian syndrome, of which PD is the most common cause. Bradykinesia refers to slowness of movement in actions that require several successive or repetitive steps, such as getting dressed or making a sandwich. Tasks requiring fine motor control such as buttoning or using utensils are typically particularly slow.

Key learning point: The one examination finding that is required to make a clinical diagnosis of Parkinson disease in a patient with a resting tremor is bradykinesia.

C) INCORRECT:

Resting tremor, muscular rigidity, and postural instability are secondary criteria; no single one of them is absolutely necessary to establish the diagnosis of PD.

D) INCORRECT:

Dysdiadochokinesia (difficulty performing rapidly alternating movements) is a sign of cerebellar disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Resting tremor, muscular rigidity, and postural instability are secondary criteria; no single one of them is absolutely necessary to establish the diagnosis of PD.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with an 8-year history of Parkinson disease presents for follow-up. She currently takes high-dose, extended-release ropinirole daily, plus carbidopa-levodopa at a dose of three tablets three times a day. She reports having moderate-to-severe involuntary choreiform movements (dyskinesias) after each dose of carbidopa-levodopa, which stop about an hour before the next dose.
Which one of the following changes to this patient’s medication regimen is most appropriate?

choices.text: Increase the dose of extended-release ropinirole
Give smaller doses of the carbidopa-levodopa more frequently

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Replacing carbidopa-levodopa with amantadine is likely to render this patient more profoundly parkinsonian, as this agent is less potent than carbidopa-levodopa and thus unlikely to provide symptomatic benefit in a patient with advanced PD. Amantadine is sometimes added to levodopa because it can help reduce dyskinesias, but it can also lead to confusion in older patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines do not have antiparkinsonian effects and should be avoided in patients with PD.

C) INCORRECT:

Replacing carbidopa-levodopa with trihexyphenidyl is likely to render this patient more profoundly parkinsonian, as this agent is less potent than carbidopa-levodopa and thus unlikely to provide symptomatic benefit in a patient with advanced PD. Trihexyphenidyl is often associated with adverse effects such as sedation or cognitive impairment in older patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing this patient’s dose of ropinirole, a dopamine agonist, will not help with the dyskinesias and may lead to adverse effects.

E) CORRECT:

The primary symptoms of Parkinson disease (PD) result from reduced activity of dopamine-secreting cells. After several years of treatment with levodopa, the effect of a dose may wear off before the next dose is given, leading to so-called motor fluctuations. If the dose is increased in an attempt to extend the duration of effectiveness, the higher dose may increase dyskinesias — the involuntary drug-induced movements that this patient is already experiencing. Giving levodopa in smaller doses at more frequent intervals may help to reduce both motor fluctuations and dyskinesias.

Key learning point: The most straightforward way to reduce motor fluctuations in a patient with Parkinson disease is to aim for a more even distribution of the carbidopa-levodopa dosing.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of tremor that does not impair any of his activities but is bothersome when he is sitting and watching television. He has not noticed other problems, but his wife has complained that he is not keeping up on walks with her like he used to. He has a history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine but is not taking any other medications.
Vital signs are normal without postural hypotension, and a comprehensive physical examination is normal. Mental status is within normal limits. Cranial nerves II through XII are tested and found normal. The patient's eye movements are normal, but his affect appears muted.
Motor examination shows normal power in all limbs but an increase in muscle tone, and movements are slow. A tremor is present at rest (right greater than left) and when the patient attempts to hold arm position. Sensory examination and reflexes are normal. On gait testing, there is no ataxia; the patient uses short, shuffling steps with decreased arm swing in the right arm.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe cognitive impairment early in the course of disease (not seen in this case) would suggest dementia with Lewy bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease that typically manifests with gait impairment and falls, cognitive impairment, slowed vertical eye movements, and parkinsonian features.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple system atrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder that manifests with autonomic dysfunction, most commonly orthostatic hypotension or urinary incontinence, and parkinsonian features or cerebellar ataxia.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced extrapyramidal syndromes can appear indistinguishable from Parkinson disease clinically, although they may be more symmetric in some cases. Patients’ medication lists should therefore be reviewed carefully when Parkinson disease is suspected to exclude drug-induced extrapyramidal syndromes.

E) CORRECT:

The classic clinical triad of Parkinson disease includes resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Key learning point: The combination of resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia is consistent with a diagnosis of Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the office because of involuntary shaking and gait abnormalities for the past year. He also reports depressed mood and diminished smell and taste. Examination shows a shuffling gait, resting tremor in the left hand, and rigidity in both arms. This patient most likely has structural changes in which of the following areas of the brain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The thalamus serves as a relay station for motor and somatosensory information between subcortical structures and the cerebral cortex. Hemorrhagic stroke is the most common cause of thalamic dysfunction and can manifest acutely with hemiparesis, paresthesia, imbalance, and autonomic and cognitive impairment. The thalamus is not involved in Parkinson disease. Moreover, afferent stimuli for every sensory system are relayed via a thalamic nucleus, except for the olfactory system. Hence, anosmia is unlikely to occur due to a lesion in the thalamus.

B) CORRECT:

The substantia nigra pars compacta contains dopaminergic neurons that transmit signals involved in movement regulation and is the part of the basal ganglia affected in Parkinson disease. Progressive degeneration of these neurons results in a clinical syndrome characterized by bradykinesia/akinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and gait abnormalities, as seen in this patient. Additional findings include sensory deficits, personality changes, and dementia.

Melanin pigments in cells of the substantia nigra are responsible for its black/dark brown appearance.

C) INCORRECT:

The caudate nucleus is a component of the striatum that is affected in Huntington disease. Although caudate nucleus atrophy can also occur in Parkinson disease, significant degeneration of neurons in this region would result in hyperkinetic symptoms (e.g., chorea, nystagmus, hyperreflexia) and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence), neither of which are reported here.

D) INCORRECT:

The internal capsule is a subcortical structure located between the basal ganglia. It contains motor and somatosensory fibers that can be damaged as a result of an ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. Hemiparesis, paresthesia, and ataxia commonly manifest after an injury to the internal capsule. The internal capsule is not involved in the pathophysiology of Parkinson disease.

E) INCORRECT:

The putamen is a component of the striatum that is involved in the regulation of movement and learning. Hemorrhagic stroke secondary to hypertension is the most common cause of putaminal dysfunction, which can manifest with acute-onset contralateral hemiplegia, sensory loss, gaze palsy, ipsilateral deviation of the eyes, stupor, and coma. Parkinson disease is not associated with structural changes in the putamen.
questions.hint: This patient's depressed mood, sensory deficits (hyposmia), and motor findings are characteristic of Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening involuntary movement of the left hand. She also reports that it takes her longer than usual to get up from a chair. Her symptoms are worse when she feels stressed at work. Neurological examination shows difficulty initiating movement and a tremor in the left hand at rest. The tremor decreases when the patient is asked to draw a circle. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clonazepam can be used to treat orthostatic tremor. The average age of onset of orthostatic tremor is 60 years of age, and this patient is 55. However, the typical clinical features of orthostatic tremor are triggered by longer periods of standing; they include tremor of the legs and a subjective sensation of instability. As this condition only affects the legs, it cannot be the cause of this patient's hand tremor.

B) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism, which can manifest with a tremor that increases with stress. However, the tremor is usually symmetric and occurs while holding positions against gravity (e.g., extending the arms in front of the body). Moreover, hyperthyroidism would not explain this patient's bradykinesia. In a patient with hyperthyroidism, other features (e.g., anxiety, hyperreflexia, weight loss, sweating) would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a drug of choice in the treatment of benign essential tremor. Essential tremor can be exacerbated by stress, as reported by this patient. However, unlike the asymmetric resting tremor seen here, essential tremor is symmetrical, worsens with voluntary movements, and resolves when the patient is completely at rest.

D) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of various forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer disease, vascular dementia, frontotemporal dementia, and dementia associated with late-stage Parkinson disease. This patient does not yet show signs of cognitive impairment and has only recently begun noticing neurological deficits.

E) CORRECT:

A non-ergot dopamine agonist such as pramipexole or ropinirole is the typical first-line treatment for Parkinson disease in young patients (< 65 years) without cognitive impairment. If symptoms are severe, combination treatment of levodopa with carbidopa and/or a COMT inhibitor (e.g, entacapone) can be initiated. Levodopa is more effective than dopamine agonists. However, levodopa therapy is usually reserved for elderly patients or patients with cognitive impairment.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) or amantadine can be used as monotherapy in patients with minimal symptoms that do not affect quality of life, or as an adjunct with dopamine agonists or levodopa in more severe cases.
questions.hint: Bradykinesia and a unilateral resting tremor (“pill-rolling tremor”) that worsens with stress and improves with voluntary movement are consistent with Parkinson disease.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents with a nine-month history of gradually worsening hand tremors and slower movements. His family notes difficulty initiating steps when walking and a tendency to take short, shuffling strides. On examination, he has minimal facial expression and a mild stooped posture. The tremor is most prominent when his hands are resting and decreases with movement. Muscle strength and sensation are intact.
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus typically presents with a triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline. The absence of urinary incontinence and cognitive symptoms, along with the presence of a resting tremor and reduced facial expression, suggests a parkinsonian syndrome rather than normal pressure hydrocephalus.

B) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by early cognitive deficits, fluctuating attention, and visual hallucinations, alongside parkinsonian features. The absence of cognitive impairment or neuropsychiatric symptoms in this patient makes Lewy body dementia unlikely. The motor symptoms described align more with Parkinson disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Essential tremor typically presents as a postural or action tremor, becoming more evident during voluntary movements. The described resting tremor that decreases with movement is inconsistent with essential tremor. Additionally, essential tremor does not usually involve bradykinesia, shuffling gait, or reduced facial expressivity.

D) CORRECT:

Parkinson disease manifests with motor symptoms such as resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. The resting tremor, often described as 'pill-rolling,' diminishes with movement. Bradykinesia is evident in slowed movements and difficulty initiating steps. Minimal facial expression and a stooped posture are also characteristic. These symptoms result from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, disrupting the balance between dopaminergic and cholinergic activity in the striatum. This imbalance affects the basal ganglia circuits, impairing motor control.

Key learning point: Parkinson disease is characterized by bradykinesia, resting tremors, a mask-like face, and a shuffling gait due to the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of a steadily worsening tremor in his left hand. His wife reports it is most noticeable at rest and lessens when he reaches for objects. He also walks with short, shuffling steps and has increased stiffness in his limbs. Neurologic examination reveals bradykinesia and cogwheel rigidity. Sensation testing is normal.
Which underlying pathologic process in the central nervous system most likely accounts for these findings?

choices.text: Loss of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the caudate nucleus
Neurofibrillary tangle accumulation in the hippocampus
Oligodendroglial alpha-synuclein inclusions in the white matter
Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loss of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the caudate nucleus is associated with Huntington disease, characterized by hyperkinetic movements like chorea, along with psychiatric and cognitive disturbances. The patient's symptoms of resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity align more with Parkinson disease, not Huntington disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Neurofibrillary tangles in the hippocampus are characteristic of Alzheimer disease, leading to memory and cognitive impairments. The patient's motor symptoms, such as resting tremor and bradykinesia, suggest a movement disorder affecting subcortical structures, not the hippocampal regions involved in Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligodendroglial alpha-synuclein inclusions are seen in multiple system atrophy, an atypical parkinsonian syndrome with features like early autonomic dysfunction. The patient's symptoms, including resting tremor and bradykinesia, are consistent with Parkinson disease, where alpha-synuclein inclusions (Lewy bodies) occur in dopaminergic neurons, not glial cells.

D) CORRECT:

Parkinson disease is characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to reduced dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway. This imbalance results in motor symptoms such as resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. The loss of dopamine disrupts the modulation of movements, with the striatum becoming more influenced by cholinergic activity. Histopathological findings include depigmentation of the substantia nigra and intracellular inclusions, underscoring the role of dopaminergic neuron loss in Parkinson disease.

Key learning point: Parkinson disease is characterized by resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and shuffling gait, and is due to degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

questions.text: A 75-year-old with a 10-year history of resting tremor and rigidity reports progressive cognitive decline over the last 8 months. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parkinson disease dementia occurs in patients with long-standing idiopathic parkinsonism, where motor symptoms like resting tremor and rigidity precede cognitive decline. This patient has a 10-year history of motor symptoms followed by an 8-month period of cognitive deterioration, aligning with this diagnosis. Parkinson disease dementia is characterized by impairments in executive function, attention, and memory, and may include mood changes and visual hallucinations. The temporal progression of motor symptoms preceding cognitive decline distinguishes it from other dementias.

Key learning point: Idiopathic parkinsonism (Parkinson's disease) is associated with dementia, particularly in the later stages, making it a common cause of dementia among the conditions listed.

B) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia is associated with stepwise cognitive decline and a history of cerebrovascular events. This patient has a long-standing history of resting tremor and rigidity, indicating a neurodegenerative disorder rather than acute vascular events, and lacks the stepwise progression typical of vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease usually presents with insidious memory loss and cortical deficits, not prominent extrapyramidal signs like resting tremor and rigidity. These motor symptoms are not typical in early or middle stages of Alzheimer disease, suggesting a different neurodegenerative process.

D) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies presents with cognitive decline either before or concurrently with motor symptoms, typically within a year of each other. This patient has a 10-year history of motor symptoms before cognitive decline, which is inconsistent with the typical presentation of dementia with Lewy bodies.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to your clinic with a one-year history of involuntary shaking and gait abnormalities. He also reports a depressed mood and reduced sense of smell and taste. On examination, he has a shuffling gait, a resting tremor in the left hand, and rigidity in both arms. This patient most likely has structural changes in which one of the following areas of the brain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The thalamus serves as a relay station for motor and somatosensory information between subcortical structures and the cerebral cortex. Hemorrhagic stroke is the most common cause of thalamic dysfunction and can manifest acutely with hemiparesis, paresthesia, imbalance, and autonomic and cognitive impairment. The thalamus is not involved in Parkinson disease. Moreover, afferent stimuli for every sensory system are relayed via a thalamic nucleus, except for the olfactory system. Hence, anosmia is unlikely to occur due to a lesion in the thalamus.

B) INCORRECT:

The caudate nucleus is a component of the striatum that is affected in Huntington disease. Although caudate nucleus atrophy can also occur in Parkinson disease, significant degeneration of neurons in this region would result in hyperkinetic symptoms (e.g., chorea, nystagmus, hyperreflexia) and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence), neither of which are reported here.

C) CORRECT:

The substantia nigra pars compacta contains dopaminergic neurons that transmit signals involved in movement regulation and is the part of the basal ganglia affected in Parkinson disease. Progressive degeneration of these neurons results in a clinical syndrome characterized by bradykinesia/akinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and gait abnormalities, as seen in this patient. Additional findings include sensory deficits, personality changes, and dementia.

Melanin pigments in cells of the substantia nigra are responsible for its black/dark brown appearance.

Key learning point: Parkinson disease is caused by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta of the basal ganglia.

D) INCORRECT:

The putamen is a component of the striatum that is involved in the regulation of movement and learning. Hemorrhagic stroke secondary to hypertension is the most common cause of putaminal dysfunction, which can manifest with acute-onset contralateral hemiplegia, sensory loss, gaze palsy, ipsilateral deviation of the eyes, stupor, and coma. Parkinson disease is not associated with structural changes in the putamen.

E) INCORRECT:

The internal capsule is a subcortical structure located between the basal ganglia. It contains motor and somatosensory fibers that can be damaged as a result of an ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. Hemiparesis, paresthesia, and ataxia commonly manifest after an injury to the internal capsule. The internal capsule is not involved in the pathophysiology of Parkinson disease.
questions.hint: This patient's depressed mood, sensory deficits (hyposmia), and motor findings are characteristic of Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of progressive movement difficulties. She reports difficulty initiating movements, and her handwriting has become smaller. On examination, she demonstrates masked facies and speaks in a monotone voice. When asked to perform rapid alternating hand movements, there is a progressive decline in both amplitude and speed. Passive manipulation of her wrist shows consistent resistance throughout the range of motion with superimposed jerky interruptions. Pull testing shows impaired postural reflexes requiring multiple steps to regain balance. What motor syndrome best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spasticity involves velocity-dependent resistance to passive movement and is associated with upper motor neuron lesions. Consistent resistance with cogwheel character and associated bradykinesia are not features of spasticity.

B) INCORRECT:

Essential tremor typically manifests as an action tremor that worsens with voluntary movement, not the bradykinesia and rigidity described. This patient's postural instability and masked facies are not characteristic of essential tremor.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar ataxia manifests with coordination difficulties, intention tremor, and wide-based gait disturbances. Masked facies, micrographia, and cogwheel rigidity are not features of cerebellar dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) can manifest with parkinsonism but is characterized by vertical gaze palsy (especially downward gaze) and early severe postural instability with frequent unprovoked falls as prominent features. This patient's clinical presentation lacks these distinguishing ocular and postural features of PSP.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient demonstrates the core features of parkinsonism: bradykinesia (evidenced by difficulty initiating movements and progressive decline in rapid alternating movements), rigidity (cogwheel rigidity with jerky interruptions during passive movement), and postural instability (impaired pull test). Masked facies and monotone voice are supportive motor findings.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and previous myocardial infarction is brought to the emergency department by his family after a fall at home. His wife reports he has become increasingly unsteady, experiences frequent falls, and has developed difficulty walking over the past 6 months. He has been taking quetiapine 25 mg daily for several years for agitation with no recent dose changes. Physical examination shows postural instability and bilateral lower extremity bradykinesia and spasticity with involuntary variable resistance during passive movement. Mental status examination shows mild cognitive impairment with executive dysfunction and poor attention. MRI brain shows multiple periventricular white matter lesions and lacunar infarcts in the basal ganglia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient demonstrates classic features of vascular parkinsonism including an advanced age (>70 years), multiple cardiovascular risk factors, gait impairment as the primary presenting symptom, bilateral, symmetric parkinsonism limited to the lower extremities, and spasticity that is greater than rigidity. Involuntary variable resistance during passive movement (paratonia) and cognitive impairment may also occur in vascular parkinsonism. The MRI findings of multiple periventricular lesions and lacunar infarcts in the basal ganglia are pathognomonic and support this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced parkinsonism typically develops within weeks to months of medication initiation or dose increase. This patient has been on a stable low dose of quetiapine for several years without recent changes, making drug-induced parkinsonism unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies typically manifests with prominent cognitive decline as the primary feature, often accompanied by visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and REM sleep behavior disorder. While parkinsonism may occur in dementia with Lewy bodies, it manifests with bradykinesia, rest tremor, and rigidity, unlike this patient’s symmetric, lower extremity-predominant presentation with spasticity and paratonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease typically manifests with asymmetric onset of bradykinesia and resting tremor, usually beginning in the upper extremities. This patient's bilateral, symmetric presentation limited to the lower extremities, presence of spasticity and paratonia, and the characteristic vascular imaging findings are not consistent with idiopathic Parkinson disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticobasal degeneration typically manifests with markedly asymmetric parkinsonism, upper limb clumsiness, and features such as alien limb phenomenon and ideomotor apraxia. This patient's bilateral, symmetric, lower extremity-predominant symptoms and lack of cortical features make corticobasal degeneration unlikely. Additionally, MRI findings in corticobasal degeneration characteristically show asymmetric focal cortical atrophy and atrophy of the basal ganglia. These findings differ from this patient's subcortical vascular lesions.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complete inability to move and incomprehensible speech that developed over 24 hours. His wife reports he has Parkinson disease and takes levodopa/carbidopa and ropinirole for motor symptoms, sertraline for depression, and clozapine for hallucinations attributed to his Parkinson disease treatment. She mentions that 5 days ago, he underwent elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged home after a 2-day stay. His medications were held perioperatively, and upon discharge, he was told to restart them gradually, but he was unsure how to do this correctly and decided to wait until his scheduled follow-up appointment with his neurologist next week. On examination, he is alert but appears rigid and cannot initiate any voluntary movements. His mucous membranes are dry. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 102; R, 18; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); and oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. Laboratory results show sodium, 145 mEq/L; potassium, 4.2 mEq/L; chloride, 105 mEq/L; bicarbonate, 22 mEq/L; BUN, 38 mg/dL; creatinine, 1.3 mg/dL; glucose, 118 mg/dL; white blood cell count, 9,800/μL; hemoglobin, 13.2 g/dL; and creatine kinase, 90 U/L. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant hyperthermia occurs within minutes to hours of exposure to volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine. It manifests with early signs including tachycardia, tachypnea, and rigidity, followed by severe hyperthermia (up to 45°C) and evidence of secondary organ damage (e.g., acute kidney injury, rhabdomyolysis). This patient's presentation, 5 days postoperative with only mild hyperthermia and normal creatine kinase, makes malignant hyperthermia unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) typically has an insidious onset over 2–4 weeks after initiation of dopamine blocking agents (e.g., antipsychotic medications) and presents with the constellation of fever, autonomic instability, lead-pipe rigidity, altered mental status, and markedly elevated creatine kinase (often > 1000 U/L). This patient's normal creatine kinase and the temporal relationship to the discontinuation rather than the initiation of medications, including an antipsychotic, make NMS less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome has acute onset (within 24 hours) and presents with a classic triad of autonomic dysfunction, neuromuscular excitability (hyperreflexia, myoclonus, clonus), and altered mental status. This patient has akinesia and rigidity rather than the neuromuscular excitability characteristic of serotonin syndrome. Additionally, serotonin syndrome typically occurs with initiation or dose increases of serotonergic medications, not after their discontinuation as occurred in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient may be at risk for antidepressant discontinuation syndrome due to the recent cessation of sertraline, his clinical presentation suggests a different cause. Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome typically presents with flu-like symptoms, insomnia, nausea, imbalance, sensory disturbances (e.g., paresthesias), and hyperarousal rather than the complete inability to move and severe rigidity seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation with inability to move, incomprehensible speech, severe rigidity, and mild hyperthermia following recent discontinuation of levodopa/carbidopa is most consistent with akinetic crisis. This condition is caused by severe dopamine deficiency following discontinuation of levodopa therapy in patients with Parkinson disease. Signs of dehydration and mild acute kidney injury with an elevated BUN-to-creatinine ratio as seen in this patient are a common complication resulting from inability to maintain adequate oral intake.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with Parkinson disease presents with a 2-day history of worsening immobility and altered mental status. Her daughter reports that the patient was recently started on metoclopramide for nausea and has been taking it for 5 days. On examination, the patient is awake but appears confused, agitated, and has severe bradykinesia with cogwheel rigidity. Vital signs are BP, 145/85; P, 75; R, 18; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Schedule routine neurology follow-up in 1-2 weeks
Obtain blood cultures and start broad-spectrum antibiotics
Obtain urgent CT brain to rule out stroke

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has acute neurological deterioration and requires immediate intervention. Delaying treatment by scheduling routine follow-up is inappropriate and may lead to further worsening of her condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is an antipsychotic with strong dopamine receptor blocking properties and is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson disease, as it severely worsens parkinsonism. This medication may precipitate an akinetic crisis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although infection may worsen parkinsonism, this patient is afebrile, and her clinical presentation is more consistent with drug-induced exacerbation. The temporal relationship with metoclopramide suggests medication-related worsening as the most likely cause.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that may precipitate or worsen parkinsonism in patients with Parkinson disease. This patient's deterioration following initiation of metoclopramide strongly suggests drug-induced worsening of her parkinsonism. Immediate discontinuation of the causal agent and optimization of dopaminergic therapy with carbidopa-levodopa is essential to prevent further neurological deterioration.

E) INCORRECT:

While stroke should be considered in patients with acute neurological changes, this patient's presentation and the temporal relationship with metoclopramide initiation are more consistent with medication-induced worsening of parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife, who is concerned about his progressive slowness over the past year. She notes his facial expression has become less animated. The patient reports a tremor in his right hand that is most prominent when he is resting. He also mentions his handwriting has become very small and cramped. On examination, he has a stooped posture and a shuffling gait with reduced arm swing. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed during the neurologic examination of this patient?

choices.text: Loss of vibratory sensation in the lower extremities
Cogwheel rigidity on passive range of motion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An intention tremor is a tremor that worsens as the hand approaches a target, which is a hallmark sign of cerebellar dysfunction. This patient has a tremor that is most prominent at rest, which is characteristic of Parkinson disease. These two types of tremors indicate distinct underlying pathologies (cerebellum vs. basal ganglia).

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of vibratory sensation indicates dysfunction of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord or a peripheral neuropathy. Although this can be seen in older adults due to various causes, such as vitamin B12 deficiency or diabetic neuropathy, it is not a characteristic feature of Parkinson disease, which primarily affects the motor system through the basal ganglia.

C) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease is a disorder of movement control and coordination, not muscle strength. Patients often feel weak due to bradykinesia and rigidity, but formal muscle strength testing is typically normal (5/5). The presence of true weakness would suggest an alternative or coexisting diagnosis, such as a myopathy or motor neuron disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperreflexia and clonus are signs of an upper-motor-neuron lesion, indicating damage to descending corticospinal tracts. This is seen in conditions such as stroke, multiple sclerosis, or spinal cord injury. Parkinson disease is a disorder of the extrapyramidal system (basal ganglia) and does not typically cause upper-motor-neuron signs; deep tendon reflexes are usually normal.

E) CORRECT:

Parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative condition that involves the progressive depletion of dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia, particularly the substantia nigra. A core clinical feature of this condition is parkinsonism, a syndrome that comprises bradykinesia along with resting tremor and/or rigidity. In Parkinson disease, this manifests as increased resistance to passive movement throughout the range of motion. When superimposed on a tremor, it creates a ratchet-like, start-and-stop quality known as cogwheel rigidity, which is a highly expected finding on examination.
questions.hint: This patient’s constellation of symptoms, including a resting tremor, bradykinesia, stooped posture, and masked facies, is consistent with Parkinson disease.
